levels.label: emerging
levels.description: Can use a calculator for basic operations (addition, subtraction, multiplication, division) but needs prompting to select the correct function keys.
levels.example_task: Use a calculator to work out 347 + 289.
levels.example_response: I type 347 + 289 = and the display shows 636. The answer is 636.
common_errors: Pressing the wrong operation key (e.g. multiplication instead of addition)
Not clearing the previous calculation before starting a new one

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Uses a calculator efficiently for multi-step calculations including fractions, decimals and negative numbers, and can interpret the display correctly.
levels.example_task: Use a calculator to work out (3.7 + 2.8) / (4.1 - 1.6). Write your answer to 2 decimal places.
levels.example_response: I enter (3.7 + 2.8) ÷ (4.1 - 1.6) = and the display shows 2.6. The answer is 2.60 (to 2 d.p.).
common_errors: Not using brackets and getting the wrong answer due to order of operations
Misreading the calculator display when it shows a recurring decimal

levels.label: secure
levels.description: Selects when a calculator is appropriate and when mental or written methods are more efficient; interprets all calculator outputs including fractions, surds and standard form.
levels.example_task: Without a calculator, estimate 4.9 × 21.3. Then use a calculator to check. Was a calculator necessary?
levels.example_response: Estimate: 5 × 21 = 105. Calculator: 4.9 × 21.3 = 104.37. My estimate was close (105 vs 104.37), so the mental method gave a good approximation. A calculator was not strictly necessary for an estimate, but useful for the exact answer.
common_errors: Always reaching for a calculator even when mental arithmetic would be faster
Not checking calculator answers against an estimate to catch input errors

levels.label: mastery
levels.description: Uses advanced calculator functions (memory, ANS, table mode, trigonometric and statistical functions) fluently, and can critically evaluate whether a calculator output is reasonable in context.
levels.example_task: A formula gives the time for a pendulum swing as T = 2π√(L/g). Use your calculator to find T when L = 0.8 m and g = 9.81 m/s². Explain why your answer is reasonable.
levels.example_response: T = 2 × π × √(0.8 ÷ 9.81) = 2 × π × √(0.08155...) = 2 × π × 0.2856... = 1.795 seconds (3 d.p.). This is reasonable because a pendulum about 80 cm long would take roughly 2 seconds per full swing, so just under 1.8 seconds for each swing is sensible. If my calculator had shown 18 seconds, I would know something was wrong.
common_errors: Entering the formula incorrectly by not grouping L/g inside the square root
Accepting a calculator output without checking whether it makes physical sense

levels.label: emerging
levels.description: Recalls basic number facts (times tables up to 12 × 12, number bonds to 20) but needs time and sometimes makes errors under pressure.
levels.example_response: 7 × 8 = 56. For 156 - 89, I count up from 89: 89 + 11 = 100, then 100 + 56 = 156, so the answer is 67.
common_errors: Confusing similar multiplication facts (e.g. 7 × 8 with 6 × 8 or 7 × 9)
Making errors with subtraction when borrowing across zeros

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Applies known number facts and standard written methods accurately to calculations involving integers, decimals and fractions, with growing speed.
levels.example_response: I need a common denominator. The LCM of 4 and 5 is 20. So 3/4 = 15/20 and 2/5 = 8/20. 15/20 + 8/20 = 23/20 = 1 3/20.
common_errors: Adding fractions by adding numerators and denominators separately (getting 5/9 instead of 23/20)
Finding a common denominator but forgetting to adjust the numerators accordingly

levels.label: secure
levels.description: Recalls and applies mathematical knowledge rapidly and accurately across number, algebra and geometry; selects the most efficient method for each calculation.
levels.example_response: 25% of £360 = 1/4 of 360 = £90. To increase £360 by 25%: £360 + £90 = £450. Alternatively, I could use the multiplier: 360 × 1.25 = £450.
common_errors: Using a long method (finding 1% then multiplying by 25) when recognising 25% = 1/4 is faster
Forgetting to add the percentage onto the original amount for a percentage increase

levels.label: mastery
levels.description: Demonstrates fluency by selecting and combining techniques from across mathematics, moving between representations confidently and spotting efficient shortcuts.
levels.example_response: I notice 998 = 1000 - 2, so 998 × 47 = 1000 × 47 - 2 × 47 = 47,000 - 94 = 46,906. This is much faster than long multiplication because I used the distributive law to create a simpler calculation.
common_errors: Not spotting near-integer shortcuts and defaulting to long multiplication
Making arithmetic slips in the subtraction step after correctly setting up the shortcut
